info: Light and Blind Control - Application Style 1

name: README
info:
This group receives data from custom devices and sends enocean frame when you simulate a switch, we are able to simulate 4 differents profiles defined by their EEP.
EEP is the EnOcean Equipment Profiles and are the fundament of interoperability between EnOcean devices of all different manufacturers.

The data is processed in such a way that one event for the click on the top line of each profile and an other one for the release on the bottom line. 



The following EEP description comes directly from Enoceean :

f6-02-01 :
    This EEP definition is based on the assumption that a RPS switch module (e.g. PTM200) is installed in a 0-STATE up position! Application Style 1 is widely used in EU but may be found in other markets as well.

f6-02-02 :
    This EEP definition is based on the assumption that a RPS switch module (e.g. PTM200) is installed in an I-STATE up position! Application Style 2 is typically used in US and CAN but may be found in other markets as well.

f6-03-01 :
    This EEP definition is based on the assumption that a RPS switch module is installed in a 0-STATE up position! Application Style 1 is widely used in EU but may be found in other markets as well.
    
f6-03-02 :
    This EEP definition is based on the assumption that a RPS switch module is installed in a I-STATE up position! Application Style 2 is typically used in US and CAN but may be found in other markets as well.

README
info:
This group accepts all the enocean frames it finds from the usb gateway, you need to set the correct serial port for this to work.
Please note that if the device is the first and only connected to the master, the serial port should be /dev/ttyUSB0

name: README
info:
This group simulates a 2 Rocker Switch (8 Buttons: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7) that can be "click"ed or "down"ed.
     "click" means the button is immediately released after beeing pressed. When "down"ed you have to release the button yourself.
     When a receiver is in LRN mode, send either `button: 0` or `button: 1` to teach in Rocker 1, send `button: 2` or `button: 3` to teach in Rocker 2 etc..
     With one USB you can send on up to 128 (0-127) channels. so you can simulate 256 Rocker switches.
     
     
     Button set-up :
        can be 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 . The button to click on the simulated rocker.
        
     Channel set-up :
        can be 0-127. The channel to send on. It's an offset off the baseId of your USB 300.
        
     Event set-up :
        can be one of "click","down","release". Defines the event to send

the text you send must have the same shape as this example:
{
    "button": 0,
    "channel": 4,
    "event": "click"
}

/!\ do not forget to modify the values !
in the actual state, the group simulate one rocker (because we have 1 ON and 1 OFF)
we highly recommand you to save one as a template and copy paste this group to have one per device you want to control.
be carefull to not duplicate any buttons !

INFO / README
info:
- This group, CUSTOM DEVICES, enables voice control of custom devices, i.e. apart from the devices of the main Gateway you can add-on here.
- 
- Any device that can be controlled via HTTP can be  integrataded here.
- 
- This sample demonstrates how to declare (publish) your custom devices, in this case Shelly Dimmer and Shelly Relays.

README
info:
This group learns Enocean devices as a real actuator would do.


***LEARNING/TEACH-IN***
    
    you have 2 methods to learn a device, you can either click on LRN, that will start a teach in for 3 sec or, if you know the senderId and the EEP of your device you can edit the "manual teach in" node with the following structure :
    
    {
        "type": "LRN",
        "senderId": "device_senderId",
        "eep": "device_EEP",
        "name": "device_name"
    }
    
    /!\ DO NOT touch the double quotes !
    
    To edit the node, double click on it then click on the three dot on the right of the text 
    Deploy your work then inject 
    
    please note that in the manual teach in, we add a name for the sensor and we don't when using the LRN node; this is not mandatory and only usefull in debug mode.
    
************
    
***DELETE***
    
    As you have 2 methods to teach in devices, there are 2 methods to delete a device. Clicking on the DEL node will start a delete for 3 sec, during this time you have to send a RF frame from the device you want to delete.
    
    if you want to manually delete a device from the actuator, edit the "manual delete" with the following structure :
    
    {
        "type": "DEL",
        "senderId": "device_senderId",
        "eep": "device_EEP"
    }
    
    /!\ DO NOT touch the double quotes !
    
    To edit the node, double click on it then click on the three dot on the right of the text 
    Deploy your work then inject 
    
    /!\ unfortunatly ther is no reset option for the actuator, a possibility might be to delete it from the flow and then to put an other, you will find it in the left column of your screen. in that case do not forget to re-link the node together as it was. 
************

***WHAT TO DO AFTER***
    
    Once you have learned your actuator you might want to use it. Depending of the incomming data, you have several possiblities. you can find example in the ENOCEAN SENSORS EXAMPLES flow
    
************

/!\ we highly recommand you to save at least one group as a template in case something bad happen

readme
info:
for manuell delete and teach in,
you need to put the correct senderId in the inject data,
otherwise they simply wont work.

they are not very important nodes as LRN and DEL allows you to start a teach in or a delete for 3 sec. within these 3 sec you need to push on button on the enocean device, it will send a RF frame and the senderId of the device will be learned in the actor node.
